explanation:
Each listed symbol is needed to decide whether any operations in OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl are actually dead (i.e. executed but removable without changing program behaviour):

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: Macro used to obtain the implementation record; its expansion may contain checks or side-effects that affect reachability/behavior of later code.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: The call shown in the static graph; needed to know whether the token lookup can fail, return a sentinel, or have side-effects that make subsequent bind call necessary (affects dead-code determination).
- OS_impl_filehandle_table: The table argument to the lookup; its layout/semantics determine whether the lookup is meaningful or a no-op in some builds.
- OS_impl_file_internal_record_t: Type of impl; required to see which fields exist and whether accessing impl->fd has side-effects or is undefined (affects whether bind use is meaningful).
- OS_object_token_t: The token type; its semantics (e.g. validity rules) affect whether the lookup and subsequent bind can ever be omitted.
- OS_SockAddr_t: Definition of Addr and AddrData is required to determine whether casting Addr->AddrData to struct sockaddr is valid and whether sa_family can take values that make code paths reachable.
- struct sockaddr / struct sockaddr_in / struct sockaddr_in6: Needed to interpret sa->sa_family, to know sizes used with sizeof(), and to determine whether the addrlen computation and bind parameters are meaningful (reachability of branches).
- AF_INET / AF_INET6: Family constants used in the switch; needed to know which branches are actually possible on target platforms.
- OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6: Compile-time macro that enables AF_INET6 handling; must be known to know whether that branch (and its code) exists and can be executed (dead vs. reachable code).
- socklen_t: Type of addrlen; included to ensure sizeof and type semantics do not change behaviour relevant to dead-code analysis.
- bind: The system call invoked; essential to know that it has side-effects (socket state, kernel state) so its presence likely prevents it from being dead code. Also to know its failure modes.
- errno / strerror: Used in the error path; need to know whether the OS_DEBUG call actually observes errno (side-effect) and whether strerror has side-effects that matter for behaviour.
- OS_DEBUG: Macro/function used to log errors; must be checked whether it compiles to a no-op (which could make that logging statement dead) or to an observable side-effect.
- OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS, OS_ERROR, OS_SUCCESS: Return codes: needed to know whether returning these values changes observable behaviour of callers (to decide if the corresponding return statements are removable without effect).

Together these symbols let an analyzer determine (a) which branches can be compiled in, (b) which branches/operations have observable side-effects (e.g. bind, logging), and (c) whether removal of any executed operation would alter program behaviour — the information needed to assess the MISRA dead-code rule for this function.
